n: (:Paper {journal: Applied Materials Today,year: 2025,title: New piezoelectric materials based on Phe-Leu and Leu-Phe dipeptides,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.apmt.2024.102564})
(:Paper {journal: Applied Materials Today,year: 2025,title: New piezoelectric materials based on Phe-Leu and Leu-Phe dipeptides,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.apmt.2024.102564})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Dropping 10 μL of a freshly prepared dipeptide solution in methanol (1 mg mL⁻¹) on the surface of a silicon substrate
- Removing the solvent by spontaneous evaporation, forced drying with warm air, or spin-coating at 3000 rpm
- Placing the silicon substrate with deposited dipeptide film in a Petri dish containing methanol to create saturated vapor (P/P₀=1)
- Sealing the Petri dish and keeping it from 10 minutes to 24 hours at room temperature
- Drying the film with warm air (45°C)})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Machine learning-assisted design of CaBi2Nb2O9-based ceramics with high piezoelectricity and thermal stability,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.11.449})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Machine learning-assisted design of CaBi2Nb2O9-based ceramics with high piezoelectricity and thermal stability,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.11.449})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Raw materials were weighed according to the nominal composition and ground in a ball mill for 12 h.
- The powders were calcined at 900 °C for 2 h and then ball milled again.
- After drying, the polyvinyl alcohol solution (PVA, 8 wt%) as a binder was added to the calcined powders and mixed well to form granulated powders.
- The granulated powders were compressed into pellets with 10 mm in diameter and 0.85 mm in thickness.
- The PVA was removed by holding the pellets at 550 °C for 4 h.
- The polycrystalline ceramics were prepared by sintering at 1140 °C for 2 h.
- The standard 0.6 mm thick ceramic samples were obtained by double-sided grinding.
- Electrodes were made of firing gold pastes at 850 °C for 10 min.})

m:
(:Step {steps: - Blended powders in ethanol for 4 h using planetary ball milling
- Calcination at 850 °C for 2 h
- Secondary ball milling
- Compressed into wafers (10 mm diameter) using 7 wt.% polyvinyl alcohol binder
- Heated at 750 °C for 1 h to remove polyvinyl alcohol
- Sintering at 1100 °C for 2 h})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: Growth and thickness effect of <100>-oriented ternary 0.06Pb(Mn1/3Nb2/3)O3-0.94Pb(Zr0.48Ti0.52)O3 ferroelectric thin films on silicon substrate by RF sputtering,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2024.116951})
m: (:Method {name: Screen printing, DC sputtering, Diffusion bonding})

n: (:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: Growth and thickness effect of <100>-oriented ternary 0.06Pb(Mn1/3Nb2/3)O3-0.94Pb(Zr0.48Ti0.52)O3 ferroelectric thin films on silicon substrate by RF sputtering,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2024.116951})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Deposition of LNO buffer layer on Pt/Ti/SiO2/Si substrate at 430 °C with Ar:O2 ratio of 8:1, sputtering power 90 W, and pressure 0.5 Pa
- Growth of PMN-PZT thin films at 550 °C with Ar:O2 ratio of 20:1, sputtering power 150 W, and pressure 0.5 Pa
- Adjustment of sputtering time to prepare PMN-PZT thin films of different thicknesses
- Annealing treatment in rapid thermal processing furnace with heating rate of 30 °C/s between 600 °C and 700 °C for 20-40 mins in air atmosphere
- Deposition of Au top electrodes on PMN-PZT thin films using DC sputtering through a shadow mask with radius of 0.15 mm})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: Enhancing piezoelectric properties of BiScO3-PbTiO3 ceramics via- incorporation of Bi(Zn1/2Ti1/2)O3 with high spontaneous polarization,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2024.116945})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weighing precursors according to stoichiometric ratio with 1 mol% excess Bi2O3 and Pb3O4
- Ball milling in alcohol for 12 h
- Drying and calcination at 750 °C for 4 h
- Two rounds of milling and drying
- Granulation with 5 wt% PVA
- Pressing under uniaxial pressure of 200 MPa
- Heat treatment at 600 °C for 4 h
- Buried firing at 1000 °C for 3 h})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: Enhanced piezoelectric properties of additively manufactured BCZT with an oriented ceramic lamellar structure formed via vat photopolymerization,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2024.116934})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: Enhanced piezoelectric properties of additively manufactured BCZT with an oriented ceramic lamellar structure formed via vat photopolymerization,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2024.116934})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Raw materials mixed with alcohol and ball milled for 24 hours
- Calcined powder obtained by heating at 1300 °C for 3 hours
- Second stage of ball milling for 1 h, 2 h, 4 h, 12 h
- Ceramic slurry prepared by mixing ceramic powder with light-sensitive oligomers, diluent, photo-initiator and dispersant (0.5 wt%) using a vacuum mixer for 300 s at 2500 rpm
- Ceramic slurry poured into VPP printer to produce ceramic green body with layer thickness set to 30 μm
- Debinding of ceramic green body completed in a tube furnace at 425 °C for 4 h with varying temperature ramp rates
- Sample kept at 550 °C for 2 h to remove residual carbon
- BCZT ceramic scaffold structure obtained by heating at 3 °C min⁻¹ to sintering temperature (1380 °C, 1400 °C, 1420 °C, 1440 °C) and furnace cooling to room temperature after holding for 3 h
- Sintered BCZT ceramics directly polarized at 15 kV for 1 h using corona poling technique
- PET film covered with ITO glued to both sides of BCZT scaffold with silver glue
- Resulting piezoelectric sensor obtained after curing for 12 h at room temperature})

n: (:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: Enhanced piezoelectric properties of additively manufactured BCZT with an oriented ceramic lamellar structure formed via vat photopolymerization,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2024.116934})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2025,title: Enhanced piezoelectric, ferroelectric and dielectric response in (Na0.5Bi0.5) TiO3-based piezoceramics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2025.178523})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2025,title: Enhanced piezoelectric, ferroelectric and dielectric response in (Na0.5Bi0.5) TiO3-based piezoceramics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2025.178523})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Stoichiometric weighing of precursors
- Ball milling for 24 hours at 300 rpm with alumina balls using acetone as mixing media
- Drying in an oven
- Calcination at 900°C for 3 hrs
- Preparation of disc-shaped pellets (~13 mm diameter) under uniaxial pressure of 200 MPa
- Sintering at 1150-1200°C for 2-4 hrs
- Density measurement using Archimedes principle
- Grinding and annealing at 500°C for 1 hr for XRD measurements
- Thinning to ~1 mm and electroding with silver paste for electrical property measurements
- Annealing at 500°C for 1 hr after electroding
- Electrical poling with DC field of 4-5 kV/mm for 15-30 min in silicone oil bath})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2025,title: Improving the thermal stability of 180° domain switching by engineering the ferroelectric/electrode interface,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.178038})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2025,title: Improving the thermal stability of 180° domain switching by engineering the ferroelectric/electrode interface,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.178038})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Dissolve equimolar quantity of Lanthanum (III) nitrate and Nickel (II) nitrate in glacial acetic acid, add ethylene glycol and stir for 1 hr
- Dissolve Ti-n butoxide in glacial acetic acid and stir for 1 hr, add ethylene glycol and stir for 1 hr
- Dissolve Lead (II) acetate in glacial acetic acid, add Zirconium (IV) n-butoxide and Titanium (IV) n-butoxide and stir
- Add distilled water and ethylene glycol and stir for 30 mins
- Add polyvinyl pyrrolidone and stir for 1 hr, filter using Whatman filter paper
- Prepare buffer layers (TiO, LNO, LNO/TiO) by spin coating at 4000 rpm for 30 s and anneal at 650 °C for 30 mins
- Deposit PZT film by spin coating at 4000 rpm for 30 s, anneal at 400 °C for 2 mins and 650 °C for 2 mins
- Repeat 12 cycles to achieve ~1000 nm thickness, anneal at 650 °C for 30 mins in open-air furnace})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2025,title: Low hysteresis and strong stability of piezoelectric stack actuators based on the Mn-doped Pb (In1/2Nb1/2) O3-Pb (Mg1/3Nb2/3) O3-PbTiO3 single crystal,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.178034})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2025,title: Low hysteresis and strong stability of piezoelectric stack actuators based on the Mn-doped Pb (In1/2Nb1/2) O3-Pb (Mg1/3Nb2/3) O3-PbTiO3 single crystal,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.178034})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Grown along [001] by the modified Bridgman method
- Cut into 6 × 6 × 0.38 mm³ as unit sheets
- Annealed at 600 °C for 4 hours and cleaned
- Deposited ultrathin conductive gold layers with a thickness of 100 nm by sputtering
- Left 0.5 mm wide insulating margins on alternating upper and lower surfaces during electrode plating
- Underwent direct current polarization (DCP) along the [001] direction at 135 °C, 1 kV/mm, and 10 minutes
- Bonded 15 layers of unit sheets using epoxy in an electrical parallel and mechanical series configuration
- Affixed zirconia ceramic sheets with a thickness of 0.5 mm to the top and bottom surfaces
- Subjected to a 5 MPa pressure applied longitudinally using an isostatic press
- Statically cured for 48 hours})

n: (:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2025,title: Low hysteresis and strong stability of piezoelectric stack actuators based on the Mn-doped Pb (In1/2Nb1/2) O3-Pb (Mg1/3Nb2/3) O3-PbTiO3 single crystal,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.178034})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2025,title: Synthesis and characterization of Eu-doped (K0.5Na0.5)NbO3 ceramics with enhanced ferroelectric, photochromic, and luminescent properties,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.177690})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2025,title: Synthesis and characterization of Eu-doped (K0.5Na0.5)NbO3 ceramics with enhanced ferroelectric, photochromic, and luminescent properties,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.177690})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Dried K2CO3 and Na2CO3 powders at 150 °C for 1 h
- Weighed powders according to compositions ((K0.5Na0.5)xEu0.01NbO3 x = 0.99, 1.00, and 1.01)
- Milled with zirconia balls in ethanol for 24 hours
- Dried at 100 °C
- Calcined at 850 °C for 4 h
- Added polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as a binder
- Prepared green ceramics by uniaxial pressing into pellets (1 mm thickness, 10 mm diameter)
- Heated to 850 °C for 1 h to burn out PVA binder
- Sintered at 1170 °C for 3 h})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2025,title: Next-generation hybrid nanogenerators using giant piezoelectric lead-free KNNS composites for sustainable self-powered electronics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.177681})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2025,title: Next-generation hybrid nanogenerators using giant piezoelectric lead-free KNNS composites for sustainable self-powered electronics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.177681})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weigh stoichiometric raw materials
- Ball-mill in alcohol for 24 hours
- Dry mixed powder in hot air oven at 100°C for 24 h
- Sieved to ensure uniform particle size
- Calcined at 900°C for 6 h
- Press fine powder into pellets using uniaxial pressing (100-200 MPa)
- Sinter pellets at 1120-1140°C for 3 h
- Disperse ceramic powder in ethyl alcohol using sonication for 3 h
- Mix dispersed powder with PDMS (0-30 wt%) and curing agent (10:1 ratio)
- Load mixture into syringe and pour into mold
- Dry at room temperature for 48 hours
- Cut dried film into 3x3 cm sheets (3 mm thickness)
- Sandwich composite film between aluminum foil electrodes})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2025,title: Significantly enhanced piezoelectric properties in PMN-PT transparent ceramics by Sm/Pr co-doping,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.177640})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2025,title: Significantly enhanced piezoelectric properties in PMN-PT transparent ceramics by Sm/Pr co-doping,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.177640})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Mix MgO and Nb2O5 powders and calcine at 1100°C for 5 hours to produce precursor columbite
- Mix MgNb2O6, PbO, TiO2, Sm2O3, and Pr6O11 and calcine at 800°C for 3 hours to generate PMN-PT powder
- Press PMN-PT powders into 13 mm-diameter cylinders by uniaxial dry pressing
- Sinter cylinders in oxygen atmosphere at 1200-1240°C
- Sinter under uniaxial pressure of 100 MPa to improve density and eliminate porosity})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2025,title: A-site and B-site cation doping engineering: A strategy to enhance strain in Pb(Zr, Ti)O3-based ceramics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.177560})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2025,title: A-site and B-site cation doping engineering: A strategy to enhance strain in Pb(Zr, Ti)O3-based ceramics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.177560})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Ball-milled La2O3 and Nb2O5 in ethanol for 12 hours
- Sieved the mixture to prepare LN additive
- Weighed PbO, TiO2, ZrO2, Bi2O3, and La2O3 based on the 0.3PT–0.65PZ–0.05BLZT formula
- Ball-milled the mixed powders with ethanol for 16 hours
- Dried the mixtures in an oven at 80 °C for 1–2 hours
- Calcined at 820 °C for 2 hours
- Secondary ball milling, drying, and sieving of synthesized powders
- Pressed granulated powders into 12 mm thick sheets with 5% polyvinyl alcohol
- Sintered at 600 °C for 4 hours to remove binder
- Sintered at 1230 °C for 2 hours to synthesize ceramic samples
- Polished ceramic surfaces to maintain uniform thickness of 0.3 mm})

n: (:Composition {property_unit: pC/N,composition: 0.3PbTiO3–0.65PbZrO3–0.05(Bi0.3La0.7)(Zn0.5Ti0.5)O3–5 wt% (La2O3+Nb2O5),property_value: 585})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2025,title: High-temperature piezoelectric properties and thermal stability of BF-BT-based ceramics by double A-site ion modification,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.177342})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2025,title: High-temperature piezoelectric properties and thermal stability of BF-BT-based ceramics by double A-site ion modification,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.177342})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weighed powder was ground with zirconia balls in ethanol for 24 h
- Dried at 100 °C for 12 h
- Calcined in air at 760 °C for 6 h at a rate of 2 °C per minute
- 8 wt% of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) was added to the powder as a binder
- Pressed under uniaxial pressure of 10 MPa to form discs with a diameter of 8 mm
- Sintered at 970°C for 6 h
- Sintered at 600 °C for 3 h to remove the PVA
- Silver paste was applied to the surfaces and fired at 450 °C for 30 min
- Polarised in silicone oil at 110 °C for 15 min using a DC field of 5 kV/cm})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2025,title: Superior piezoelectric performance in ytterbium-substituted high-TC Bi5Ti3FeO15,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.177343})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Raw materials were mixed and milled with ZrO2 balls in ethanol for 12 h
- After drying, the mixture was calcined at 750 °C for 3 h
- Resulting powder was granulated with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binders and pressed into disks 12 mm in diameter and 1.0 mm in thickness
- Each disk was heated at 650 °C to burn off the PVA binder
- Sintered at 1050–1060 °C for 3 h at a heating rate of 3 °C/min in an aluminum oxide crucible})

m:
(:Step {steps: - Synthesize ZnNb2O6 precursor at 1000 °C
- Ball mill mixture of ZnNb2O6 with Pb3O4, HfO2, and TiO2
- Calcined at 850 °C for 2 h
- Pressed and sintered at 1050 °C for 2 h
- Polarized in silicone oil at 120 °C under 4 kV/mm for 30 min})

m:
(:Step {steps: - Ball milling with zirconia balls and anhydrous ethanol as the media for 24 h
- Pre-sintering at 800 °C for 2 h
- Pelletising with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA)
- Ageing for 24 hours
- Subjecting to a pressure of 16 MPa and debonding
- Sintering in a muffle furnace at temperatures between 1010 and 1030°C})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Enhanced electrical properties in textured Bi4Ti3O12 ceramics with negative strain,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2025.01.301})
(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Enhanced electrical properties in textured Bi4Ti3O12 ceramics with negative strain,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2025.01.301})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Synthesized [001]-oriented BTO template powders from Bi2O3 and TiO2 using molten salt method with equal molar ratio of NaCl and KCl in 1:1 wt ratio
- Sintered template powder at 1100 °C for 1 h
- Prepared BTO matrix powders by solid-state reaction with Bi2O3 and TiO2 powders weighed according to stoichiometric ratio
- Calcined raw materials at 700 °C for 2 h
- Ball milled calcined powder for 48h-72h to achieve small particle size
- Mixed template and matrix powders by ball milling at ~60 rpm using xylene and ethanol as solvents
- Added 5 vol% BTO template to solution and stirred for 1 h
- Performed tape casting with blade gap of 210 μm
- Dried tapes at room temperature for 8-10h
- Cut tapes into 10 × 10 mm squares and laminated under 75 MPa pressure for 1-3h
- Burned off organics at 600 °C for 3h
- Heated green bodies in tube furnace from 650 °C to 1000 °C at 10 °C/min rate
- Sintered green bodies in oxygen atmosphere at 950 °C for 0-6 h})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Enhanced piezoelectric properties of high-temperature calcium bismuth titanate piezoceramics via oxygen vacancy modulation,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2025.01.250})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Enhanced piezoelectric properties of high-temperature calcium bismuth titanate piezoceramics via oxygen vacancy modulation,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2025.01.250})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Powders were ground using a planetary ball mill for 12 h with anhydrous ethanol as the solvent.
- The ball-milling mixture was dried at 70 °C for 6 h.
- The dried powders were calcined for 4 h at 850 °C.
- 0.2 wt% MnO2 was added to the calcined powders.
- The calcined powders were ground using the planetary ball mill for 12 h and dried again.
- A 6 wt% polyvinyl alcohol binder (PVA) was added to the calcined powders.
- The powders were pressed into discs under a pressure of 6–8 MPa.
- The discs were heated at 600 °C for 2 h to remove the PVA.
- The pellets were sintered at 950 °C-1050 °C for 2.5 h in the air.})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Simultaneously achieving high piezoelectric properties and excellent temperature stability in Mn added lead-based piezoelectric ceramics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2025.01.274})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Simultaneously achieving high piezoelectric properties and excellent temperature stability in Mn added lead-based piezoelectric ceramics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2025.01.274})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Mixed precursors according to stoichiometric ratio and accurately weighed
- Ball milled for 18 h
- Dried powder calcined at 850 °C for 3 h
- Added MnCO3 and ball-milled for 18 h
- Pressed dried powder into disks using polyvinyl butyral as binder
- Removed organics at 600 °C for 3 h
- Sintered green discs at 1150–1250 °C for 3 h
- Coated both sides with silver electrodes and held at 550 °C for 30 min
- Polarized in silicone oil at 150 °C with DC electric field of 3 kV/mm for 35 min})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Domain engineering via liquid nitrogen quenching in bismuth sodium titanate-based relaxor-ferroelectric thin films,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2025.01.144})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Domain engineering via liquid nitrogen quenching in bismuth sodium titanate-based relaxor-ferroelectric thin films,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2025.01.144})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Stirred mixture at room temperature at 700 rpm
- Allowed solution to polymerize for seven days
- Deposited 6 layers on Pt/Ti/SiO2/Si substrate via spin-coating (500 rpm for 10 s, then 4000 rpm for 30 s per layer)
- Applied heat treatments: evaporation at 200 °C, pyrolysis at 500 °C, annealing at 750 °C, each for 5 min
- Repeated sequence 6 times
- Some samples further heat-treated in nitrogen atmosphere at 750 °C for 30 min
- Deposited Pt top electrodes by RF magnetron sputtering})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Microstructure and electric properties in PSN-PMN-PT textured ceramics by template grain growth technology,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2025.01.105})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Microstructure and electric properties in PSN-PMN-PT textured ceramics by template grain growth technology,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2025.01.105})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Synthesize 0.15PSN-0.57PMN-0.28PT matrix powder using traditional solid state reaction method
- Sinter mixed raw materials at 750 °C for 2 h to produce pure perovskite matrix powder
- Synthesize plate-like BT templates with [001] orientation by topochemical transformation technique
- Slice, stack, and compress embryo strips for 30 min at 70 °C with 10 MPa pressure
- Discharge organic matters by sintering at 550 °C for 2 h
- Subject samples to isostatic pressing at 200 MPa for 1 min
- Sinter samples in air atmosphere at 1200–1270 °C for 0–11 h})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Microstructural evolution and enhanced piezoelectric properties of 0.5Pb(Ni1/3Nb2/3)O3-0.16PbZrO3-0.34PbTiO3 ceramics textured by two-dimensionally-dispersed template grain growth,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.12.350})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Microstructural evolution and enhanced piezoelectric properties of 0.5Pb(Ni1/3Nb2/3)O3-0.16PbZrO3-0.34PbTiO3 ceramics textured by two-dimensionally-dispersed template grain growth,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.12.350})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Ball-milling of raw materials with zirconia balls for 24 h
- Drying at 90°C
- Calcination at 850°C for 4 h (heating rate: 5°C/min)
- Addition of 0.2 wt% Li2CO3 as sintering aid
- Ball-milling with zirconia balls for 48 h
- Drying at 90°C
- Mixing with organic materials and ball-milling for 24 h
- Removal of air bubbles using vacuum chamber for 15 min
- Aging process for 2 h at 15 rpm
- Tape casting at 1 m/min with blade gap of 85 µm
- Preparation of BT-included thin sheets via tape casting at 1 m/min with blade gap of 8 µm
- Lamination under 10 MPa at 60°C
- Warm isostatic pressing (WIP) at 25 MPa and 65°C for 20 min
- Cutting into 10 mm × 10 mm pieces
- Firing at 300°C and 600°C for 5 h each (heating rate: 1°C/min)
- Cold isostatic pressing (CIP) at 200 MPa for 1 min
- Sintering at 900°C to 1025°C for 15 h under O2 atmosphere
- Application of Ag paste and firing at 700°C for 10 min
- Poling at 3.5 kV/mm for 20 min in silicone oil})

(:Paper {journal: Materials Today Communications,year: 2025,title: Comparative analysis of electromechanical performance of morphotropic phase boundary (MPB) based normal ferroelectric and non-MPB based relaxor ferroelectric perovskites,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.mtcomm.2024.111283})

(:Paper {journal: Materials Today Communications,year: 2025,title: Comparative analysis of electromechanical performance of morphotropic phase boundary (MPB) based normal ferroelectric and non-MPB based relaxor ferroelectric perovskites,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.mtcomm.2024.111283})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Mixed precursors homogenously for 12 hours using a planetary ball mill with zirconia jar and zirconia balls in presence of acetone as milling agents
- Calcined the homogenous mixed powder at 900 °C for 5 hours
- Mixed the calcined powder with 3 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) solution in deionized water as organic binder
- Pressed into pellets of 12 mm and 14 mm diameter using uniaxial pressure die at 100 MPa
- Sintered green pellets at 1190 °C for 2 hours inside a muffle furnace sealed in alumina crucible using MgO and pre calcined as spacer powder
- Crushed the sintered pellet and annealed at 600 °C for 4 hours to remove mechanical strains
- Covered dense sintered pellets with silver paste to create electrodes and baked at 250 °C for 45 minutes for poling
- Polarized silver coated ceramic pellets in silicone oil bath at room temperature for 1 hour by applying DC electric field of 40 kV/cm})

n: (:Paper {journal: Materials Today Communications,year: 2025,title: Comparative analysis of electromechanical performance of morphotropic phase boundary (MPB) based normal ferroelectric and non-MPB based relaxor ferroelectric perovskites,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.mtcomm.2024.111283})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: BiFeO3-BaTiO3 piezoelectric ceramics with high depolarization temperature by fine tuning phase boundary,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.10.375})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: BiFeO3-BaTiO3 piezoelectric ceramics with high depolarization temperature by fine tuning phase boundary,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.10.375})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weigh raw materials according to stoichiometric formula
- Add excess 2 mol% Bi2O3 powders
- Planetary mill powders using ethanol as dispersant with zirconia balls for 12 h
- Dry mixed oxides
- Calcinate at 800 °C for 6 h
- Re-mill calcined powders with ethanol and zirconia balls for 12 h
- Dry and mix with 7 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA)
- Press into 10 mm diameter pellets
- Burn out PVA at 300 °C for 1 h
- Sinter at 970 °C for 3 h
- Polish samples to 0.5 mm thickness
- Paste with high-temperature silver electrodes
- Fire at 850 °C for 30 min
- DC poling with 4 kV/mm electric field at 80 °C in silicone oil bath for 20 min
- Age samples for 24 h before electrical characterizations})

n: (:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: BiFeO3-BaTiO3 piezoelectric ceramics with high depolarization temperature by fine tuning phase boundary,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.10.375})

(:Step {steps: - Raw materials prepared according to calculated ratios
- Planetary ball mill for 4 hours
- Drying slurry at 100 °C
- Calcination at 850 °C for 2 hours
- Adding 7 wt.% polyvinyl alcohol binder
- Pressing powder into 10 mm diameter discs
- Calcination at 1100 °C for 2 hours})

(:Paper {journal: Materials Today Communications,year: 2025,title: Improvement of structure and electrical properties of multiple elements co-doped KNN crystals grown by SFSSCG method,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.mtcomm.2024.111119})

(:Paper {journal: Materials Today Communications,year: 2025,title: Improvement of structure and electrical properties of multiple elements co-doped KNN crystals grown by SFSSCG method,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.mtcomm.2024.111119})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Raw materials powders were heated to 120 °C for 6 h
- Raw materials were weighed and mixed into a ball-milled tank with anhydrous ethanol and zirconia ball medium
- Mixture was ball-milled at 410 r/min for 24 h and dried
- Obtained mixture was sieved by a 100-mesh sifter
- Calcined at 750 °C for 6 h
- Calcined powders were subjected to secondary ball milling for 24 h
- Sieved through a 150-mesh sifter after drying
- Powders were compacted to disks of 25 mm diameter and 2-3 mm thickness
- Normal sintering in air at 1108 °C for 21 h in a muffle furnace
- As-grown crystals were cut out from the ceramic matrix and ground into disc-like specimens with a thickness of 0.5-0.6 mm
- Sintered samples were poled under a DC field of 30 kV/cm at 100°C for 30 min in a silicone oil bath})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Evolutions of dielectric, ferroelectric, and piezoelectric properties with temperature in a nonergodic BNT-BT-KNN single crystal,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.11.355})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Evolutions of dielectric, ferroelectric, and piezoelectric properties with temperature in a nonergodic BNT-BT-KNN single crystal,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.11.355})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Mix precursor powders in ethanol via ball milling for 15 h
- Dry the mixture
- Place mixture into a covered alumina crucible
- Calcinate at 810 °C for 5 h
- Heat to 1200 °C and slowly cool to 850 °C to promote single crystal growth
- Coat cut crystal wafers with silver paste and sinter at 850 °C for 30 min
- Pole single crystals by immersing in silicone oil and applying a DC electric field of 40 kV/cm for 10 min at room temperature})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Enhanced piezoelectric properties of BiFeO3-BaTiO3 lead-free ceramics by shifting phase boundary via simultaneous adjusting component and quenching technique,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.11.054})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Enhanced piezoelectric properties of BiFeO3-BaTiO3 lead-free ceramics by shifting phase boundary via simultaneous adjusting component and quenching technique,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.11.054})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weigh raw materials according to stoichiometric ratios
- Mix well in absolute ethyl alcohol for 24 h with ZrO2 balls
- Dry slurry in oven at 95 °C
- Calcinate at 800 °C for 4 h
- Add 5 wt% PVA to dry powder
- Press into wafers with 18 Mpa pressure (1 mm thickness, 12 mm diameter)
- Remove PVA at 600 °C for 120 min
- Sinter at 990-1000 °C for 3h
- Polish with 800 mesh sandpaper
- Prepare samples with silver paste at 600 °C for 20 min
- Polarize ceramic samples under DC electric field of 4-5 kV/mm at 85 °C for 30 min
- Anneal BLF-0.3BT, BLF-0.31BT, and BLF-0.32BT at 970 °C for 30 min and quench in air})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Development of a novel Bi4Ti3O12/chitosan/rGO piezoelectric bio-composite for mechanical energy harvesting: Output energy optimization using response surface methodology modelling,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.11.249})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Development of a novel Bi4Ti3O12/chitosan/rGO piezoelectric bio-composite for mechanical energy harvesting: Output energy optimization using response surface methodology modelling,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.11.249})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Milled Bi2O3 and TiO2 powders using agate mortar and pestle, dried at 150°C
- Synthesized Bi4Ti3O12 via solid-state reaction
- Extracted chitosan from shrimp shells using NaOH and HCl treatments
- Purified chitosan by dissolving in acetic acid, neutralizing with NaOH, washing, and drying
- Synthesized graphene oxide (GO) via modified Hummers' method: mixed graphite, NaNO3, H2SO4, added KMnO4, heated, added H2O2, purified by centrifugation
- Reduced GO to rGO using hydrazine hydrate at 100°C for 12 h
- Prepared BiTO/Chitosan/rGO composites: dispersed graphene in acetic acid, added chitosan, added BiTO, ultrasonicated, degassed, dried at 60°C
- Poled samples with 6 kV/mm DC field for 15 min, aged for 24 h})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Synergetic enhancement in the piezoelectric coefficient and electromechanical factor in PYN-PMN-PT ceramics via texture engineering,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.11.138})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Synergetic enhancement in the piezoelectric coefficient and electromechanical factor in PYN-PMN-PT ceramics via texture engineering,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.11.138})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Synthesize YbNbO4 and MgNb2O6 precursors using Yb2O3, MgO and Nb2O5
- Ball-mill stoichiometric PbO, TiO2, MnO2, YbNbO4 and MgNb2O6 precursors in ethanol with ZrO2 media
- Calcinate the mixture at 775 °C for 2h
- Ball mill the calcined mixture again
- Add 3 vol% BaTiO3 templates into the slurry
- Burn out binders
- Cold isostatic press green samples at 200 MPa
- Sinter textured ceramics between 1150 and 1200 °C for 6h
- For random ceramics, follow same procedure without BaTiO3 templates})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Effects of boron and manganese doping on electrical poling and properties of 0.94(Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3-0.06BaTiO3 piezoelectric ceramics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.11.085})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: Effects of boron and manganese doping on electrical poling and properties of 0.94(Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3-0.06BaTiO3 piezoelectric ceramics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.11.085})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Ball-milled raw materials for 24 h in ethanol using zirconia balls
- Dried and calcined powders at 900 °C for 4 h
- Added 1 mol% B3+ to pre-synthesized undoped and 1 mol% Mn3+ doped BNT-6BT
- Uniaxially pressed at 100 MPa to form disc samples
- Mixed with 5 wt% PVA as a binder
- Re-pressed via cold isostatic press (CIP) at 150 MPa
- Burnt out PVA binder at 600 °C for 4 h
- Sintered at 1150 °C for 12 h in air})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: BaTiO3 doped PEO coating on pure Mg with enhanced antibacterial, antifouling and corrosion resistance properties,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.11.033})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: BaTiO3 doped PEO coating on pure Mg with enhanced antibacterial, antifouling and corrosion resistance properties,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.11.033})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Mechanically ground Mg samples with SiC paper up to 1000 grit
- Ultrasonically cleaned in ethyl alcohol
- Dried in cold air
- Used Mg plates as anode and stainless steel chamber as cathode
- Applied pulse reverse power with constant current of 2 A/dm² for 660 s under 500 Hz frequency and 15% duty cycle
- Prepared electrolyte with 20 g/L Na2SiO3 + 4 g/L KF + 2 g/L NaOH
- Added BaTiO3 powder to electrolyte for PEO-BTO2 and PEO-BTO5
- Cooled solution using water-cooling system at 30 ± 5 °C
- Rinsed samples in distilled water and dried in warm air after PEO treatment})

n: (:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2025,title: BaTiO3 doped PEO coating on pure Mg with enhanced antibacterial, antifouling and corrosion resistance properties,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.11.033})

(:Paper {journal: Next Materials,year: 2025,title: Enhanced functionalities in flexible poly (vinylidene fluoride-trifluoroethylene)/cerium oxide doped sodium bismuth titanate [P(VDF-TrFE)/NBT-CeO2] ceramic polymer composite films: A comprehensive investigation of piezoelectric, pyroelectric, and ferroelectric properties,isOpenAccess: true,doi: 10.1016/j.nxmate.2024.100416})

(:Paper {journal: Next Materials,year: 2025,title: Enhanced functionalities in flexible poly (vinylidene fluoride-trifluoroethylene)/cerium oxide doped sodium bismuth titanate [P(VDF-TrFE)/NBT-CeO2] ceramic polymer composite films: A comprehensive investigation of piezoelectric, pyroelectric, and ferroelectric properties,isOpenAccess: true,doi: 10.1016/j.nxmate.2024.100416})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Disperse NBT-0.6CeO2 (0.05–0.25 vol%) in P(VDF-TrFE) matrix using 10 wt% DEC solvent
- Fabricate thin films (0.8–1 µm thickness) by spin-coating onto glass substrates pre-coated with aluminum electrodes
- Form a metal-insulator-metal (MIM) structure by depositing additional aluminum electrodes onto the spin-coated films
- Anneal samples at 100°C to optimize crystallinity
- Prepare bulk samples by solution casting method (thickness of 30 µm) for piezoelectric measurements
- Perform DC poling at 65°C under a high electric field of 200 MV/m for 60 min})

(:Paper {journal: Materials Research Bulletin,year: 2025,title: Flexible PVDF-Ba0.97Ca0.03TiO3 polymer-ceramic composite films for energy storage, biosensor, mechanosensor, and UV–visible light protection,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.materresbull.2024.113116})

(:Paper {journal: Materials Research Bulletin,year: 2025,title: Flexible PVDF-Ba0.97Ca0.03TiO3 polymer-ceramic composite films for energy storage, biosensor, mechanosensor, and UV–visible light protection,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.materresbull.2024.113116})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Dissolve 1.74 g of PVDF in 20 ml of N,N-dimethylformamide at 60 °C
- Add 10, 20, 30, 40, or 50 wt.% of BCT3 filler after four hours of mixing
- Stir the solution at 500 rpm for an additional four hours
- Cast the solution in a cleaned petri dish and anneal at 100 °C for 5 h
- Peel off the films, cut into square pieces, and hot press at 100 °C under 125 kg/cm² pressure})

(:Paper {journal: Materials Science in Semiconductor Processing,year: 2025,title: Enhanced in-situ piezoelectric properties and thermal stability of lead-free BiFeO3-BaTiO3 ceramics by local structural heterogeneity,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.mssp.2024.108948})

(:Paper {journal: Materials Science in Semiconductor Processing,year: 2025,title: Enhanced in-situ piezoelectric properties and thermal stability of lead-free BiFeO3-BaTiO3 ceramics by local structural heterogeneity,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.mssp.2024.108948})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weighed raw materials according to the chemical formula
- Ball-milled for 24 h
- Pre-fired in a muffle furnace at 780 °C for 4h at a heating rate of 2 °C/min
- Added 8 wt% PVA as a binder
- Pressed into 8 mm diameter disks at a uniaxial pressure of 12 MPa
- Sintered at 600 °C for 3 h to remove PVA
- Sintered at 1000 °C for 6 h to obtain ceramic wafers
- Polarized ceramic discs with double-sided silver electrodes in silicon oil at 120 °C under a DC field of 5 kV/cm for 20 min})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: Enhanced piezoelectric properties of KNN-based ceramics by synergistic modulation of phase constitution, grain size and domain configurations,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2024.116874})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: Enhanced piezoelectric properties of KNN-based ceramics by synergistic modulation of phase constitution, grain size and domain configurations,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2024.116874})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Ball milling with ethyl alcohol for 12 h at 300 r/min
- Drying the powders in an oven
- Calcining at 890 °C for 6 h
- Ball-milling again for 12 h
- Drying and sieving the powder mixtures
- Pressing into pellets with a diameter of 10 mm at 200 MPa using a cold isostatic press
- Sintering: heating to 1190 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min, then rapidly cooling to 1090 °C and dwelling for 3–15 h before naturally cooling down})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: Water-mediated production of K0.5Na0.5NbO3 piezoelectric ceramics with cold-sintering assisted route: Enhanced dielectric properties,isOpenAccess: true,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2024.116815})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Powder mixing
- Calcination at 700-875 °C for 5 h
- Re-milling for 24 h at 250 rpm using planetary ball mill with ethanol and yttrium stabilized zirconia balls
- Cold sintering-assisted (CSA) experiments using SPS machine in vacuum
- Application of 45 kN force (400 MPa) over 40 min with temperature increase of 5 °C/min to 200 °C
- Thermal post-treatment at 850 °C for 25 min with 245 MPa pressure
- Re-oxidation for 6 h at 850 °C in oxygen})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: Random fields-triggered strain enhancement in BNT-based materials,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2024.116805})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: Random fields-triggered strain enhancement in BNT-based materials,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2024.116805})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weighed materials and ethanol are poured into a jar and ball milled for 24 h with ZrO2 ball
- Dried powders are calcined at 850 °C for 6 h
- Raw powders are mixed according to the proportion of the corresponding components, and ethanol is poured into a jar and ball milled for 24 h with ZrO2 balls once again
- Dried mixed powders are granulated into a floc with 8 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as a binder
- Pressed into disks (1 mm in thickness and 10 mm in diameter) under a pressure of 10 MPa
- Disks were buried in the calcined powders and sintered at 1150 °C for 3 h in an air atmosphere
- Heating rate of the sintering process from RT to 1000 °C is 5 °C/min, which is 3 °C/min beyond 1000 °C
- Samples with silver electrodes are processed at 600 °C for 10 min})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2024,title: Synergistic regulation of Nd2O3 doping and components accommodation to attain enhanced electrical performance in BiScO3-PbTiO3 high temperature ceramics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.177019})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Ball-milled in ethanol with zirconia balls for 24 h
- Dried in oven
- Calcined at 850 °C for 3 h
- Additional 12 h ball milling in ethanol
- Dried and granulated with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol
- Sieved through 80-mesh screen
- Uniaxially dry pressed into samples (10 mm diameter, 1.5 mm thickness)
- Binder removed at 550 °C
- Sintered at 3 °C/min to 1120-1200 °C for 2 h in air})

(:Step {steps: - Evaporation at 80 °C
- Heating at 80 °C for 30 min to dry completely
- Calcination at 650 °C for 3 h in air
- Pressing ceramic powders uniaxially at 880 MPa in a 6 mm die
- Sintering at various temperatures (780 °C or 835 °C for 3 h)})

(:Paper {journal: Heliyon,year: 2024,title: Influence of Nd3+ ion on piezoelectric studies in lead barium niobate ferroelectric ceramics for device applications,isOpenAccess: true,doi: 10.1016/j.heliyon.2024.e40471})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weigh and mix precursors in stoichiometric ratio
- Add methanol as dispersing agent and mix for 1 hour
- Add PVA (5 wt%) as binder with PVA-to-ceramic powder ratio of 1:20
- Press into pellets using uniaxial hydraulic press at 150 MPa for 3 min
- Sinter in air atmosphere at 1150 °C for 4 hours})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2024,title: High performance (K,Na)NbO3-based textured ceramics for piezoelectric energy harvesting,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.10.279})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2024,title: High performance (K,Na)NbO3-based textured ceramics for piezoelectric energy harvesting,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.10.279})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Ball-milling precursors in anhydrous ethanol for 24 h
- Calcining at 850 °C for 5 h
- Mixing matrix and NaNbO3 templates in ethanol/toluene co-solvent with PVB binder and MnO2 sintering aid
- Tape casting slurry to green tapes with thickness of 30–50 μm
- Drying, cutting, stacking, and uniaxially pressing at 15 MPa at 70 °C for 20 min
- Removing organic binder at 600 °C
- Heating to 1190 °C, then rapidly cooling to 1090 °C and dwelling for 10 h})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2024,title: The impact of chemical inhomogeneity in calcinated powders on grain growth behavior and piezoelectric properties of lead-free KNN-based ceramic,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.10.374})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2024,title: The impact of chemical inhomogeneity in calcinated powders on grain growth behavior and piezoelectric properties of lead-free KNN-based ceramic,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.10.374})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weighing high-purity raw materials according to stoichiometry ratio
- Ball milling with ethyl alcohol for 12 h at 300 rpm
- Drying the powders
- Dividing powders into 4 batches and calcining at 800, 850, 900, and 950 °C
- Pressing part of powders into compacts (10 mm diameter) at 200 MPa using cold isostatic press (group A)
- Subjecting residual powders to another ball-milling for 24 h (group B)
- Pressing into pellets under same conditions as group A
- Sintering all pellets by two-step sintering: heating to 1190 °C at 10 °C/min, cooling to 1090 °C and dwelling for 5 h
- Printing silver paste on both sides of samples and baking at 600 °C for 30 min to form electrodes})

n: (:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2024,title: The impact of chemical inhomogeneity in calcinated powders on grain growth behavior and piezoelectric properties of lead-free KNN-based ceramic,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.10.374})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2024,title: Synergistic enhancement of electrical characteristics in Sr2+ and Zr4+ Co-doped BaTiO3 ceramics through multiphase coexistence regulation at room temperature,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.10.314})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Mixed precursors in stoichiometric ratios and ball milled in ethanol at 400 rpm for 12 h
- Dried the mixture
- Fired at 1200 °C for 2 h
- Blended calcined material with 5 wt% PVA
- Compacted into discs (15 mm diameter, 1 mm thickness) at 10 MPa
- Heated to 650 °C at 5 °C/min and held for 2 h to remove PVA
- Sintered at 1400 °C at 5 °C/min for 3 h in air
- Coated with silver paste and cured at 600 °C for 0.5 h
- Polarized in silicone oil bath at 40 °C under 30 kV/cm DC field for 20 min})

m:
(:Step {steps: - Dried carbonates at 120 °C for more than 2 h
- Mixed raw materials by ball-milling in ethanol
- Calcined powder mixture twice at 800 °C for 2 h
- Milled calcined powders for 12 h
- Pressed into disks with 12.7 mm diameter using PVA as binder
- Fired green compacts at 600 °C to remove PVA binder
- Sintered in ambient atmosphere at 1000–1020 °C for 2 h
- Mechanically polished sintered disks to ~0.35 mm thickness})

(:Paper {journal: Solid State Communications,year: 2024,title: Improving piezoelectric performance in PMN-0.26 PT single crystal via low frequency AC poling,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ssc.2024.115714})

(:Paper {journal: Solid State Communications,year: 2024,title: Improving piezoelectric performance in PMN-0.26 PT single crystal via low frequency AC poling,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ssc.2024.115714})
m:
(:Step {steps: - The as-grown single crystals were oriented by the rotating XRD method
- [001]-oriented square slices were cut with size 4 × 4 × 0.8 mm³
- A layer of Ni was covered on the (001) plane crystal slices
- Au electrode was sputtered on the crystal slices for poling and subsequently electrical performance measurement
- All samples were annealed at 600 °C for 10 h and then air-cooled to room temperature
- Samples were placed at room temperature for 2 days to completely release the internal stress
- During the DCP procedure, samples were poled at different electric field with dwelling 5 min at 25 °C
- For the ACP procedure, the ACP signal was generated by a Function Generator and amplified by a high-voltage amplifier
- The symmetry triangular wave was chosen to study the influence of other poling conditions on performance during the ACP procedure
- The electrical performance was measured 24 h after poling})

n: (:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2024,title: Systematic approach for high piezoelectric AlN deposition,isOpenAccess: true,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.176723})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Substrates cleaned in ultrasonic baths: 5 minutes in Decon neutracon solvent, 5 minutes in WashBryte solvent, 5 minutes in DI water
- Substrates dried under N2 flow and loaded into deposition system under residual pressure around 10E-7 mbar
- Al target cleaned in pure Ar (30 sccm) at 300 W for 10 min
- 5 min in Ar/N2 plasma to reach stable reactive conditions
- Deposition using magnetron powers of 70 and 400 W, and Ar & N2 flows of 20 and 40 sccm})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2024,title: Low field assisted electrocaloric effect and energy storage responses through optimization of morphotropic phase boundary by sintering temperature for lead-free Ba0.95Ca0.05Sn0.09Ti0.91O3 ceramics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.176519})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2024,title: Low field assisted electrocaloric effect and energy storage responses through optimization of morphotropic phase boundary by sintering temperature for lead-free Ba0.95Ca0.05Sn0.09Ti0.91O3 ceramics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.176519})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Barium acetate, calcium acetate, and tin acetate were dissolved in 2-ethylhexanoic acid at 80°C until a clear solution was obtained.
- C16H36O4Ti was mixed in the same solvent and added to the previous solution.
- The final solution was stirred and mixed for 1 h at 80°C.
- The solution was dried to obtain BCST powder.
- The BCST powder was calcined at 1000°C for 4 h in a muffle furnace.
- The calcined powder was ground with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) solution until fine powder was obtained.
- Pellets were prepared by compressing the powder under 5 ton pressure.
- The pellets were sintered at 1100 and 1200°C for 5 h.})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2024,title: Comprehensive electrical properties and thermal stability of PNT-xPZ-PT ceramics via composition optimization,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.176609})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2024,title: Comprehensive electrical properties and thermal stability of PNT-xPZ-PT ceramics via composition optimization,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.176609})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weighed raw materials according to stoichiometric ratio
- Milled in alcohol with zirconia balls for 12 hours
- Dried and presintered at 750 °C for 2 hours
- Additional ball-milling for 24 hours
- Mixed with 7 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA)
- Compressed into 13 mm diameter disks
- Sintered at 1180-1270 °C in air for 3 hours})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2024,title: Simultaneous giant strain and electrostrictive coefficient in lead-free BNT-ST-BT ergodic relaxor thin films on Pt/TiO2/SiO2/Si substrates,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.176514})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2024,title: Simultaneous giant strain and electrostrictive coefficient in lead-free BNT-ST-BT ergodic relaxor thin films on Pt/TiO2/SiO2/Si substrates,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.176514})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weigh precursors according to stoichiometric ratio with 12 mol% excess sodium acetate and 2 mol% excess bismuth acetate
- Stir mixture at 80°C for one hour to obtain precursor solution
- Adjust solvent content to achieve 0.4 mol/L solution concentration
- Deposit solution on pretreated Pt/TiO2/SiO2/Si substrates by spin coating (1500 r/min for 10 s then 3000 r/min for 40 s)
- Perform pyrolysis at 150°C for 3 min to evaporate solvent
- Perform pyrolysis at 410°C for 10 min to remove organic components
- Anneal at 725°C for 3 min for crystallization
- Repeat deposition and heating procedures 6 times
- Prepare Au electrodes by DC sputtering})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2024,title: A high-power piezoelectric ceramic with great electrical properties and temperature stability,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.176362})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of Alloys and Compounds,year: 2024,title: A high-power piezoelectric ceramic with great electrical properties and temperature stability,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2024.176362})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Materials were mixed in deionized water and ball-milled for 6 h
- Powder was pressed into blocks and calcined at 850 °C for 2 h
- Calcined powder was ball-milled for 12 h
- Dried powder combined with PVA was pressed into pellets
- Green bodies were heated at 550 °C for 3 h to remove PVA
- Green bodies were sintered at 1250 °C for 2 h in sealed alumina crucible
- Sintered ceramics were ground to 1 mm thickness
- Silver electrodes were fired on surfaces at 720 °C for 20 min
- Ceramics were poled in silicon oil at 130 °C under 35 kV/mm DC field
- Polarized ceramics were aged for 24 h at room temperature})

(:Composition {property_unit: pC/N,composition: 0.075Pb(Mn1/3Sb2/3)O3-(0.93)Pb(Zr0.48Ti0.52)O3,property_value: 318})

(:Paper {journal: Materials and Design,year: 2024,title: Establishing room-temperature multiferroic behaviour in bismuth-based perovskites,isOpenAccess: true,doi: 10.1016/j.matdes.2024.113498})
(:Paper {journal: Materials and Design,year: 2024,title: Establishing room-temperature multiferroic behaviour in bismuth-based perovskites,isOpenAccess: true,doi: 10.1016/j.matdes.2024.113498})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weighing raw powders according to stoichiometric formulae
- Ball milling for 24 h in polypropylene containers with ethanol and ZrO2 balls
- First calcination at 850°C for 2 h
- Second calcination at 900°C for 4 h
- Re-milling for 24 h
- Two-stage calcination at 950°C for 4 h and 1000°C for 2 h
- Milling for 4 h to reduce particle size
- Mixing with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol binder
- Uniaxial cold-pressing into pellets
- Sintering at 1100°C for 2 h in sealed alumina crucibles
- Drying at 120°C for 12 h})

n: (:Composition {property_unit: pC/N,composition: 0.5(0.94Bi0.5Na0.5TiO3-0.06BaTiO3)-0.5BiFe0.8Mn0.2O3,property_value: 27.6})

(:Paper {journal: Materials Today Communications,year: 2024,title: Superior piezoelectric performance in holmium-substituted high-TC Bi5Ti3FeO15,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.mtcomm.2024.111118})

(:Paper {journal: Materials Today Communications,year: 2024,title: Superior piezoelectric performance in holmium-substituted high-TC Bi5Ti3FeO15,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.mtcomm.2024.111118})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weighed chemicals were wet-milled in polyethylene bottles with ZrO2 balls for 12 h in ethanol
- Calcination at 750 °C for 3 hours
- Calcined powders were milled, dried, ground, and granulated with a polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder
- Granulated powders were pressed into discs with diameters of 12.5 mm and thicknesses of 1.0 mm at a pressure of 150 MPa
- Pellets were heated to 650 °C for 60 min to burn out the binder
- Samples were sintered at 1080 °C for 3 h
- Sintered samples were polished to a thickness of approximately 0.5 mm
- Silver paste was screen-printed onto the two parallel polished surfaces, followed by firing at 570 °C for 30 min})

(:Paper {journal: Materials Today Communications,year: 2024,title: Synthesis and characterization of photopolymerizable piezoelectric KNN-based methacrylated hyaluronic acid hydrogel scaffolds,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.mtcomm.2024.110948})

(:Paper {journal: Materials Today Communications,year: 2024,title: Synthesis and characterization of photopolymerizable piezoelectric KNN-based methacrylated hyaluronic acid hydrogel scaffolds,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.mtcomm.2024.110948})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Dried precursors for 12 hours at 120 °C
- Planetary ball milling in 100% ethanol for 3 h at 125 rpm
- Dried slurry using rotary evaporator
- Ground with agate mortar and pestle
- Sieved with 250 μm mesh
- Uniaxially pressed calcination pellets under 5 MPa
- Calcination at 801.5 °C for 4 hours
- Milled calcined pellets in 100% ethanol for 30 minutes at 125 rpm
- Dried slurry using rotary evaporator
- Ground with agate mortar and pestle
- Sieved with 150 μm mesh
- Uniaxially pressed sintering pellets under 30 MPa
- Isostatically pressed under 200 MPa
- Sintered at 1103.5 °C for 2 hours
- Surface finish to 1 μm
- Thermally etched at 1037.5 °C for 7 minutes
- Carbon coated for SEM/EDX analysis})

(:Paper {journal: Materials Today Physics,year: 2024,title: Achieving ultra-high resistivity and outstanding piezoelectric properties by co-substitution in CaBi2Nb2O9 ceramics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.mtphys.2024.101598})

(:Paper {journal: Materials Today Physics,year: 2024,title: Achieving ultra-high resistivity and outstanding piezoelectric properties by co-substitution in CaBi2Nb2O9 ceramics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.mtphys.2024.101598})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Precisely weigh powders according to stoichiometric ratios
- Transfer to a nylon tube for 12 h of ball milling in an alcohol dispersing medium
- Dry the mixed slurry
- Calcinate at 850 °C for 4 h
- Mill again for 12 h
- Press 0.3 g of ceramic powder into a disc (8 mm diameter, 1.3 mm thickness) under 250 MPa pressure
- Cover the surface of green bodies with ceramic powder of the same composition
- Sinter in air at 1100 °C for 4 h to obtain dense ceramic sheets
- Polish samples to 1 mm thickness for dielectric properties and resistivity characterization
- Apply and cure platinum electrodes on both sides
- Prepare samples with thicknesses of 0.5 mm and 0.2 mm for piezoelectric and ferroelectric properties characterization, respectively})

(:Paper {journal: Chemical Engineering Journal,year: 2024,title: Giant piezoelectricity in fluoropolymer fiber mats achieved by corona poling in water,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.cej.2024.157756})

(:Paper {journal: Chemical Engineering Journal,year: 2024,title: Giant piezoelectricity in fluoropolymer fiber mats achieved by corona poling in water,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.cej.2024.157756})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Electrospinning of P(VDF-TrFE) 80/20 from 12 wt% MEK solution using a grounded rolling collector
- First thermal annealing (1A) at 140 °C for various times (10, 60, 180, 360, 720, 1440, and 2880 min)
- Second thermal annealing (2A) below TC (110, 115, 125, and 130 °C) for 1 day
- Corona-charging in air at room temperature for 30 min
- Corona-charging in water using AC corona poling at 500 kHz})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2024,title: Effect of epoxy resin addition on the acoustic impedance, microstructure, dielectric and piezoelectric properties of 1–3 connectivity lead-free barium zirconate titanate ceramic cement-based composites,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.10.251})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2024,title: Effect of epoxy resin addition on the acoustic impedance, microstructure, dielectric and piezoelectric properties of 1–3 connectivity lead-free barium zirconate titanate ceramic cement-based composites,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.10.251})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Calcined barium carbonate, zirconium dioxide, and titanium dioxide at 1200 °C for 2 h
- Pressed BZT powder into a disc shape of ~15 mm diameter and ~1.5 mm thickness at ~85 MPa
- Sintered BZT discs at 1450 °C for 2 h
- Poled BZT discs using an electric field of 1.5 kV/mm at 50 °C for 30 min in a silicone oil chamber
- Cut poled BZT ceramic using a diamond saw in a parallel direction along with the polarization axis
- Mixed Portland cement powder, water, epoxy resin, and hardener as the matrix phase with w/c ratio of 0.35 and epoxy resin to hardener volume ratio of 7.5
- Filled the mixture into the cut areas of the BZT ceramic
- Cured samples in a controlled chamber at 60 °C for 5 days at 98 %RH})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2024,title: Enhancing the piezoelectric performance of novel PZT-PMS-PSN piezoelectric ceramics by fine-tuning the monoclinic phase,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.09.287})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2024,title: Enhancing the piezoelectric performance of novel PZT-PMS-PSN piezoelectric ceramics by fine-tuning the monoclinic phase,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.09.287})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Sc2O3 and Nb2O5 powders were wet-mixed via ball milling for 12 h
- Calcination at 1050 °C for 6 h to obtain the precursor ScNbO4
- Mixed with PbO, ZrO2, TiO2, MnO2, and Sb2O3
- Calcined at 850 °C for 2 h to achieve the desired composition of PZT-PMS-PSN
- Resultant powder was crushed for 8 h and then dried
- Fine powder was mixed with the PVA binder at a mass concentration of 7 %
- Pressed to form Ø10mm pellets at a pressure of 150 MPa
- Binder was cremated at 800 °C for 2 h
- Sintered at 1180 °C for 2 h
- Sintered pellets were polished to reach about 0.5 mm
- Both sides of the sample were coated with silver paste and fired at 800 °C for 10 min
- Polarization at 180 °C in a silicone oil bath at a DC field strength of 5 kV/mm for 30 min})

(:Paper {journal: Sensors and Actuators A: Physical,year: 2024,title: Revealing multiphase coexistence of R-O-T phases in BaTiO3-CaTiO3-BaSnO3 electroceramics for energy harvesting and storage response with piezo actuation,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.sna.2024.115932})

(:Paper {journal: Sensors and Actuators A: Physical,year: 2024,title: Revealing multiphase coexistence of R-O-T phases in BaTiO3-CaTiO3-BaSnO3 electroceramics for energy harvesting and storage response with piezo actuation,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.sna.2024.115932})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weigh each powder in stoichiometric ratio
- Wet mill for 24 hours in ethanol medium using polyethylene bottles containing zirconia balls stabilized with yttria
- Dry in an oven at 80°C overnight
- Calcinate at 1200°C for 4 hours in a zirconia crucible
- Pelletize into disc-shaped samples using a 5 wt.% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder
- Sinter at 1450°C for 4 hours at a heating rate of 2°C per minute
- Polish the sintered pellets on silicon carbide paper
- Coat with silver paint on both sides and dry for 30 minutes at 600°C})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2024,title: Study on curie temperature mechanism and electrical properties of BiFeO3-doped (Ba,Ca) (Ti,Sn)O3 ceramics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.09.282})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2024,title: Study on curie temperature mechanism and electrical properties of BiFeO3-doped (Ba,Ca) (Ti,Sn)O3 ceramics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.09.282})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weighed raw materials according to composition (1-x)(Ba0.95Ca0.05)(Ti0.89Sn0.11)O3-xBiFeO3 (x = 0, 0.1, 0.5, 0.9 mol%)
- Milled with ethanol for 16 h
- Dried at 100 °C
- Calcined at 1150 °C for 3 h
- Re-milled with ethanol for 16 h
- Pressed into disks of 9 mm diameter using 3% PVA solution as binder
- Fired at 600 °C for 2 h
- Sintered at 1400 °C for 3 h
- Polished and coated with silver paste on surfaces
- Fired at 800 °C for 30 min to obtain electrode
- Poled at 50 kV/cm DC field for 30 min at room temperature in silicone oil bath})

n: (:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2024,title: Study on curie temperature mechanism and electrical properties of BiFeO3-doped (Ba,Ca) (Ti,Sn)O3 ceramics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.09.282})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2024,title: An in-depth comparison of dielectric, ferroelectric, piezoelectric, energy storage, electrocaloric, and piezocatalytic properties of Ba0.92Ca0.08Zr0.09Ti0.91O3 and Ba0.92Ca0.08Sn0.09Ti0.91O3 piezoceramics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.09.358})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2024,title: An in-depth comparison of dielectric, ferroelectric, piezoelectric, energy storage, electrocaloric, and piezocatalytic properties of Ba0.92Ca0.08Zr0.09Ti0.91O3 and Ba0.92Ca0.08Sn0.09Ti0.91O3 piezoceramics,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.09.358})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Stoichiometric ratios of precursors were mixed
- Grinding in a mortar and pestle for 2 h
- Milling in ethanol solution with zirconia balls for 4 h
- Drying the resulting solutions
- Pulverizing the obtained lumps
- Calcining at 1200 °C for 4 h in air
- Regrinding the granulated powders
- Molding into disk-shaped pellets with 1 wt% PVA binder
- Heating pellets at 650 °C for 1 h to burn off PVA
- Sintering binder-free pellets at 1400 °C for 4 h in air})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials,year: 2024,title: One-step synthesis of a piezoelectric hybrid BNNT/BaTiO3 composite and its application in bone tissue engineering,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jmbbm.2024.106758})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials,year: 2024,title: One-step synthesis of a piezoelectric hybrid BNNT/BaTiO3 composite and its application in bone tissue engineering,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jmbbm.2024.106758})
m:
(:Step {steps: - 1 g colemanite, 80 mg Fe2O3, 500 mg BaCO3, and 500 mg TiO2 were mixed
- The mixture was subjected to ball milling for 15 h at a rotational speed of 300 rpm
- 2 mL of 13.8 M ammonia solution was added to the mixture, which was then ball-milled for an additional 3 min at the same rotational speed
- The resulting mixture was transferred onto a silicon carbide plate (3 cm × 2 cm)
- The ammonia solution was evaporated by heating the plate on a hot plate set to 150 °C
- The SiC plate with the residual mixture was placed into a tubular furnace
- The furnace temperature was gradually increased to 1300 °C and maintained for 3 h under a continuous flow of NH3 gas
- The NH3 gas flow was stopped at 975 °C, and the furnace was allowed to cool to room temperature})

n: (:Paper {journal: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials,year: 2024,title: One-step synthesis of a piezoelectric hybrid BNNT/BaTiO3 composite and its application in bone tissue engineering,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jmbbm.2024.106758})

n: (:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2024,title: Significantly enhanced piezoelectric response in Aurivillius Bi3TiNbO9 ceramics simply by Ce doping,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.09.364})

(:Paper {journal: Ceramics International,year: 2024,title: Significantly enhanced piezoelectric response in Aurivillius Bi3TiNbO9 ceramics simply by Ce doping,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.ceramint.2024.09.364})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weigh raw materials according to nominal composition
- Ball mix for 24 h with anhydrous ethanol and zirconia balls medium
- Dry and calcine at 800 °C for 3 h
- Ball mill for 24 h again
- Granulate dried powders with polyvinyl alcohol solution (PVA, 5 wt%)
- Press into green pellets of 13 mm diameter and about 1.0 mm thick under 120 ± 10 MPa
- Fire green pellets at 650 °C for 3 h to burn off PVA
- Sinter at 1065–1105 °C for 3 h in air with 5 °C/min followed by furnace-cooling})

(:Paper {journal: Materials Chemistry and Physics,year: 2024,title: Effects of electrical and mechanical properties of Ba0.92Ca0.08Zr0.05Ti0.95O3 ceramics with lanthanum dopants,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.matchemphys.2024.129965})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Solution was placed in the oven at 120 °C for 10 h to obtain gels
- Gels were calcined at 900 °C for 2 h to form precursor powders
- Powders were pressed into disks with a diameter of 20 mm
- Disks were embedded in alumina
- Disks were sintered at 1300 °C for 4 h in air with a heating rate of 5 °C/min})

(:Paper {journal: Nano Energy,year: 2024,title: Enhanced buoyancy and propulsion in 3D printed swimming micro-robots based on a hydrophobic nano-fibrillated cellulose aerogel and porous lead-free piezoelectric ceramics,isOpenAccess: true,doi: 10.1016/j.nanoen.2024.110254})

(:Paper {journal: Nano Energy,year: 2024,title: Enhanced buoyancy and propulsion in 3D printed swimming micro-robots based on a hydrophobic nano-fibrillated cellulose aerogel and porous lead-free piezoelectric ceramics,isOpenAccess: true,doi: 10.1016/j.nanoen.2024.110254})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Raw materials mixed with ethanol and ball-milled for 24 h
- Ethanol-ceramic slurry dried in an oven and ground into powder
- Calcination at 1250 °C for 3 h with heating rate of 5 °C/min
- Calcinated powders ground and sieved using 63 µm mesh
- Dense BCZT ceramics formed by uniaxial-pressing with PVA binding agent
- Green body heated to 500 °C for 2 h with ramp rate of 1 °C/min to burn out organics
- High temperature sintering at 1400 °C for 10 h with ramp rate of 5 °C/min
- Porous BCZT ceramics manufactured via freeze casting with PVA and ammonium polyacrylate
- Slurry unidirectionally frozen at -80 °C and freeze-dried to form green body
- Porous green bodies sintered at same conditions as dense BCZT})

n: (:Paper {journal: Nano Energy,year: 2024,title: Enhanced buoyancy and propulsion in 3D printed swimming micro-robots based on a hydrophobic nano-fibrillated cellulose aerogel and porous lead-free piezoelectric ceramics,isOpenAccess: true,doi: 10.1016/j.nanoen.2024.110254})

n: (:Composition {property_unit: pC/N,composition: Ba0.85Ca0.15Zr0.1Ti0.9O3 (dense),property_value: 467})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: Improved piezoelectric performance of PbNb2O6-based ceramics via K+ modification,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2025.117193})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: Improved piezoelectric performance of PbNb2O6-based ceramics via K+ modification,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2025.117193})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weigh raw materials according to stoichiometric ratio
- Ball-mill with zirconia balls in nylon jars for 12 h
- Add 2 wt% PbO to compensate volatilization
- Dry at 120 °C
- Calcinate at 900 °C for 4 h
- Re-mill for 6 h
- Mix with PVA binder and sieve
- Press into pellets (12 mm diameter, 1.2 mm thickness) under 15 MPa
- Fire at 500 °C for 2 h for binder burn-out
- Sinter at 1190-1250 °C for 1 h
- Control cooling at 3 °C/min till 600 °C
- Natural cooling below 600 °C})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: High mechanical quality factor and high piezoelectric coefficient achieved via acceptor-modified invisible boundary,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2024.117100})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: High mechanical quality factor and high piezoelectric coefficient achieved via acceptor-modified invisible boundary,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2024.117100})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weigh raw chemicals according to stoichiometric ratio
- Ball-mill for 12 h with ethyl alcohol as the medium
- Dry the mixture
- Calcinate at 1250 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min
- Ball-mill calcined powder again in ethanol for 12 h
- Dry at 90 °C for 3 h
- Press mixture into pellets with 5 wt% PVA as a binder
- Heat at 500 °C for 5 h to volatilize PVA
- Sinter pellets at 1450 °C for 4 h in air})

(:Paper {journal: Materials Research Bulletin,year: 2025,title: Enhanced piezoelectric response of Na0.5Bi0.5TiO3-BaTiO3 lead free ceramics by tuning the local polar heterogeneity,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.materresbull.2024.113231})

(:Paper {journal: Materials Research Bulletin,year: 2025,title: Enhanced piezoelectric response of Na0.5Bi0.5TiO3-BaTiO3 lead free ceramics by tuning the local polar heterogeneity,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.materresbull.2024.113231})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Dried raw materials at 120°C for 5 hours
- Mixed by ball milling for 12 hours with ethanol as medium
- Calcined at 850°C for 2 hours
- Second ball milling for 12 hours to reduce particle size
- Granulated by passing through 80 mesh sieve
- Added PVA aqueous solution (5 wt.%) as binder
- Heated green bodies to 800°C for 2 hours to remove binder
- Sintered at 1140°C-1180°C for 2 hours
- Polished ceramic disks heated to 1100°C for 1 hour and rapidly cooled in air})

(:Step {steps: - Precisely weigh raw materials according to stoichiometric ratios
- Ball mill with ethanol as dispersion medium for 8 h
- Dry and calcine at 850 °C for 4 h
- Dry, grind, and compress into disks (8 mm diameter) under 250 MPa pressure
- Sinter at 1100 °C for 4 h})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: Improved hydrostatic piezoelectric property via incorporation of porous PZT ceramics into 1–3 type PZT-polymer composites: Design to fabrication,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2024.117046})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: Improved hydrostatic piezoelectric property via incorporation of porous PZT ceramics into 1–3 type PZT-polymer composites: Design to fabrication,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2024.117046})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Prepare CIM feedstock with KICET-PZT8 piezoelectric powder, paraffin wax, and EVA
- Fabricate preform of 1-3 type composite using CIM machine (NEX-500, NISSEI Japan)
- Sinter PZT composite preform at 1250 °C for 2 h
- Pour polymer (301, EPOTEK) into sintered preform
- Cure polymer-poured specimens at 80°C for 12 h
- Machine cured specimens into optimized shapes
- Apply room-temperature-curing silver electrodes
- Polarize by applying electric field of 2.5 kV/mm for 20 min in silicone oil bath at 120°C})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: Spark plasma sintering of high-TC calcium bismuth niobate (CaBi2Nb2O9) with superior piezoelectric performance,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2024.117065})

(:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: Spark plasma sintering of high-TC calcium bismuth niobate (CaBi2Nb2O9) with superior piezoelectric performance,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2024.117065})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Weigh raw materials according to stoichiometric ratio
- Mix by ball-milling with ZrO2 balls in ethanol for 12 hours
- Dry the mixtures
- Calcinate at 850 °C for 2 hours
- Additional 24-hour ball-milling under same conditions
- Grind and granulate with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder
- Press into discs (12 mm diameter, 1 mm thickness) under 150 MPa pressure
- Remove PVA by heating at 650 °C
- Sinter in muffle furnace (1150 °C for 3 hours for CaBi2Nb2O9, 1100-1140 °C for 3 hours for Tm-substituted CBN)
- For textured ceramics: place powders in graphite die (10 mm inner diameter), heat to 990 °C for 3 minutes at 100 °C/min under 60 MPa load
- Deform in larger graphite die (20 mm inner diameter) at 1130 °C for 5 minutes under 40 MPa load
- Anneal in muffle furnace at 1000 °C for 4 hours in air})

n: (:Paper {journal: Journal of the European Ceramic Society,year: 2025,title: Spark plasma sintering of high-TC calcium bismuth niobate (CaBi2Nb2O9) with superior piezoelectric performance,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2024.117065})

(:Paper {journal: Composites Part B: Engineering,year: 2025,title: Synergistically triggering macroscopic polarization and dynamic reconfiguration of CdS@SnS2 heterojunction to enhance piezo-photocatalytic nitrate reduction,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.compositesb.2024.112108})

(:Paper {journal: Composites Part B: Engineering,year: 2025,title: Synergistically triggering macroscopic polarization and dynamic reconfiguration of CdS@SnS2 heterojunction to enhance piezo-photocatalytic nitrate reduction,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.compositesb.2024.112108})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Dissolve 4 mmol TAA and 2 mmol SnCl4·5H2O in 80 mL absolute ethanol, stir for 30 min
- Transfer mixture to Teflon-lined autoclave, heat at 160 °C for 12 h
- Cool to room temperature, wash, centrifuge, dry at 60 °C to obtain SnS2
- Combine 20 mmol Cd(NO3)2·4H2O with 60 mL ethylenediamine, stir until transparent
- Add 60 mmol thiourea, stir for 30 min
- Transfer mixture to Teflon-lined autoclave, heat at 160 °C for 12 h
- Wash, centrifuge, dry at 60 °C to obtain CdS
- Disperse x mmol CdS in 80 mL absolute ethanol, ultrasonicate for 15 min
- Add mixture of 2 mmol SnCl4·5H2O and 4 mmol TAA, stir at room temperature for 30 min
- Transfer mixture to Teflon-lined autoclave, heat at 160 °C for 12 h
- Cool to room temperature, wash, centrifuge, dry at 60 °C to obtain CS-x/2 samples
- Combine 0.5 g CdS and 0.5 g SnS2 with 50 mL deionized water, sonicate for 2 h
- Filter and dry to obtain RCS})

(:Paper {journal: Nuclear Engineering and Design,year: 2025,title: Diffusion bonding of PZT disc to nickel wear plate for fabrication of high temperature under-sodium ultrasonic transducers,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.nucengdes.2025.113832})
m: (:Method {name: Screen printing, DC sputtering, Diffusion bonding})

n: (:Paper {journal: Nuclear Engineering and Design,year: 2025,title: Diffusion bonding of PZT disc to nickel wear plate for fabrication of high temperature under-sodium ultrasonic transducers,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.nucengdes.2025.113832})
m:
(:Step {steps: - PZT discs coated with silver using screen printing with silver paste, followed by firing at 800°C in air
- Ni wear plates machined from Ni-200 rods, surface ground to 10 μm planarity and 1 μm roughness
- Ni wear plate coated with silver using DC sputtering to 6 μm thickness
- Coated Ni wear plate heated in flowing hydrogen gas at 700°C for 2 h
- Additional 3 μm silver coating applied to Ni wear plate
- PZT discs and Ni wear plates bonded at 275°C or 400°C under 20 MPa pressure for 1 h in vacuum
- Thermal cycling between 250°C and room temperature for bonded samples
- Repoling of PZT discs bonded at 400°C using DC poling unit at 150°C in silicone oil with 15 kV for 15 min})

n: (:Paper {journal: Nuclear Engineering and Design,year: 2025,title: Diffusion bonding of PZT disc to nickel wear plate for fabrication of high temperature under-sodium ultrasonic transducers,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.nucengdes.2025.113832})

(:Paper {journal: Applied Radiation and Isotopes,year: 2025,title: Novel smart materials with high curie temperatures: Eu1.90Dy0.10Ge2O7, Eu1.90La0.10Ge2O7 and Eu1.90Ho0.10Ge2O7,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.apradiso.2024.111655})

(:Paper {journal: Applied Radiation and Isotopes,year: 2025,title: Novel smart materials with high curie temperatures: Eu1.90Dy0.10Ge2O7, Eu1.90La0.10Ge2O7 and Eu1.90Ho0.10Ge2O7,isOpenAccess: false,doi: 10.1016/j.apradiso.2024.111655})
m:
(:Step {steps: - Combined precursors in stoichiometric ratios
- Heated at 800 °C for 2 h
- Heated to 1150 °C for 10 h in pure alumina crucibles under open atmosphere
- Slowly cooled
- Formed ceramic discs (1 mm thickness, 10 mm diameter)
- Compacted using uniaxial pressing under 250 MPa with 2 wt% PVA binder
- Heated at 600 °C for 30 min to eliminate organic additives
- Sintered at 1400 °C for 4 h
- Applied silver paste to surfaces and fired at 650 °C for 1 h
- Polished on emery paper (1200 grit)
- Fired at 650 °C for 1 h to form surface electrodes
- Applied electric field (9-18 kV/mm) in silicon oil bath at 120 °C for 30 min
- Aged for 24 h prior to piezoelectric characterization})
